idCitation.otherCitDet: DWR Data Disclaimer: This dataset was developed by the State of California, Department of Water Resources, for uses beneficial to the State. The information is available upon request to interested members of the public. While the Department believes the information to be reliable and made efforts to assure its reliability at the time the information was compiled, the information is provided "as is". The Department is not responsible for the accuracy, completeness, quality or legal sufficiency of the information. Any expressed or implied warranties, including, but not limited to, the implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for purpose ARE SPECIFICALLY DISCLAIMED. Neither the Department nor the State of California shall be held liable for any direct, indirect, incidental, special, exemplary or consequential damages (including, but not limited to: procurement of substitute goods or services; loss of use, data or profits; or business interruption), however caused and on any theory of liability, whether in contract, strict liability or tort, arising in any way out of the use of this information. This disclaimer applies to use of the information alone and to its aggregate use with other information, data or programs. The information contained in each of the basin descriptions at this site was obtained from information on file in the offices of the Department of Water Resources and limited additional information. Recent studies may contain additional, more up-to-date information. To obtain the most up-to-date information about the basin you are interested in, please contact the local management agency listed near the end of the basin description. The State of California and the Department of Water Resources hereby specifically retain any intellectual property interest, including copyright, that they may hold in the information provided, whether the information is in the form of data, files, text images, photography or maps. The Department requests that persons receiving and using this information not make it available to others for their re-use. Instead, interested third parties should be encouraged to contact the Department for copies, in order to ensure that the information is obtained from the source that developed it, that can provide the greatest degree of reliability.

dataIdInfo.idAbs: The dataset is a feature class showing the boundaries of 515 groundwater basins and subbasins as defined by the California Department of Water Resources as last modified by the Basin Boundary Emergency Regulation adopted on October 21, 2015 and subsequent modifications requested through the Basin Boundary Modification Request Process. The file is in ESRI geodatabase format and is intended for use with compatible GIS software. Groundwater basins are represented as polygon features and designated on the basis of geological and hydrological conditions - usually the occurrence of alluvial or unconsolidated deposits. When practical, large basins are also subdivided by political boundaries, as in the Central Valley. Basins are named and numbered per the convention of the Department of Water Resources. The associated data are considered DWR enterprise GIS data, which meet all appropriate requirements of the DWR GIS Spatial Data Standards. DWR makes no warranties or guarantees, either expressed or implied, as to the completeness, accuracy or correctness of the data, nor accepts or assumes any liability arising from or for any incorrect, incomplete or misleading subject data. The official DWR GIS Data Steward for this dataset is Brett Wyckoff, who may be contacted at 916-902-6779, or at brett.wyckoff@water.ca.gov. Comments, problems, improvements, updates, or suggestions should be forwarded to the official GIS Data Steward as available and appropriate.
dataIdInfo.idPurp: Bulletin 118 defines the recognized groundwater basins and subbasins throughout the State of California. The Bulletin 118 document provides information on these basins/subbasins and the nature and extent of groundwater occurrence and management within the State. The Bulletin 118 dataset makes the geographic locations and extent of the 515 basins/subbasins publicly available, for use in external mapping/GIS applications.

graphOver.bgFileDesc: A series of blue polygons depicting groundwater basins.

Caution: It is possible to plot part or the entire map at a scale that exceeds the 1:250,000 resolution of the map. However, the groundwater basin data can be no more accurate than the 1:250,000 resolution base map on which it was plotted.

dataIdInfo.suppInfo: Origination of Data - The basin boundaries for the groundwater basin map were primarily defined using geologic contacts and hydrogeologic divides. Specifically, the identification of the groundwater basins was initially based on the presence and areal extent of unconsolidated alluvial soils identified on 1:250,000 scale geologic maps provided by the California Department of Conservation, Division of Mines and Geology. The identified groundwater basin areas were then further evaluated through review of relevant geologic and hydrogeologic reports, well completion reports, court-determined adjudicated basin boundaries, and contact with local agencies to refine the basin boundaries. The 6.2 version of DWR’s Bulletin 118 dataset is available at: https://data.cnra.ca.gov/dataset/ca-bulletin-118-groundwater-basins1. The current dataset was updated at the time the latest Bulletin 118 document was produced, and is based on geological maps and other information available at that time. There have been minor corrections to the dataset since that time, as described in the data lineage. Additional Contacts - Contacts Statewide Data Steward: Brett Wyckoff Senior Engineering Geologist California Department of Water Resources Sustainable Groundwater Management Office (916) 902-6779 Brett.Wyckoff@water.ca.gov Region Office Data Sub-stewards: Northern Region Office Michelle Dooley Supervising Engineering Geologist (530) 529-7380 Michelle.Dooley@water.ca.gov North-Central Region Office Bill Brewster Senior Engineering Geologist (916) 376-9622 Bill.Brewster@water.ca.gov South-Central Region Office Dane Mathis Supervising Engineering Geologist (559) 230-3354 Dane.Mathis@water.ca.gov Southern Region Office Tim Ross Supervising Engineering Geologist (818) 549-2345 Timothy.Ross@water.ca.gov Update Frequency: Changes to the dataset are made on an infrequent and irregular basis. Minor changes are occasionally made and will be documented in the metadata. Substantial changes, such as the extent of a basin boundary, must be completed as part of a public process, where the changes are proposed and public review and comment are welcomed before any changes are finalized. README_GSP Alternatives The Sustainable Groundwater Management Act (SGMA) established a process for local agencies to develop an Alternative in lieu of a Groundwater Sustainability Plan (GSP) (see Water Code §10733.6) for evaluation by DWR. An Alternative is required to be submitted to DWR for review no later than January 1, 2017, and every 5 years thereafter. GSP alternatives encompass entire groundwater basins so a separate feature class was not created. To extract the basins where alternatives were submitted, use the most recent feature class of Groundwater Basin boundaries from the DWR production atlas i08_B118_CA_GroundwaterBasins. Join the table GSP_Alternatives.xlsx to the groundwater basins feature class using the Basin_Subbasin _Number field in both the feature class and the table. Note: A geodatabase feature class table can be created from the Excel table and used for the Join.

report.measDesc: Dataset appears to have all features. Due to the nature of the subject matter, edge to edge coverage of California does not exist.

Of 515 Features: All have Basin_Number, Basin_Subbasin_Number, Basin_Name, Basin_Subbasin_Name, and Region_Office populated. Date_Record_Last_Edited, Record_Edited_By and Comments have some <null> values present by design.

Locational Quality: Pursuant to Water Code 10722 and 23 California Code of Regulations 340.4 “a basin’s boundaries shall be as identified in Bulletin 118.” This report is not being made by a licensed land surveyor, and is not analogous to a positional accuracy statement as stipulated in the California Public Resources Code.14.2.

prcStep.stepDesc: Metadata Update - December 09, 2010 B118_v3_BasinBoundaries_NAD83_unprojected file was developed from B118v3NAD27UTM10 (dated 15-September-2006) which had a UTM 10 NAD 27 projection. The new file projection is defined as Latitude/Longitude NAD 83 and was converted using ESRI's Project tool in a two step process. Set one changed the Datum from NAD27 to NAD 83. The second step was to re-project the file from Universal Transverse Mercator 10 to Lat/Long Geographic projection for the use of CASGEM.

Metadata Update – June 20, 2012 The shapefile B118_BasinBoundaries_v4_1.shp replaces B118_v3_BasinBoundaries_NAD83_unprojected.shp. Changes in the update include restoration of the northern portion of the North Yuba subbasin which was inadvertently removed during the 2003 B-118 Update. Also, the DWR District field (DWR_DIST) in the feature attribute table has been replaced by Regional Office Field (Regional_O). Basin boundary features in previous versions that were comprised of multiple polygons are now represented by single multi-part polygons.

In an effort to realign locations of groundwater basins and subbasins, a process was set up to review the boundaries of all groundwater basins and subbasins to ensure they were aligned with the most current geologic boundaries. This process step was undertaken to review and correct some of the errors related to geologic boundaries. We reviewed each basin written description to provide a list of which basin boundaries referred to a geologic boundary and subsequently needed to have their geologic boundary portions reviewed. Once we had a list of the basins that needed review, we reviewed them with the using the California Geologic Survey maps of 1:250,000 scale (Regional Geoloci Map Series and The Geologic Atlas of California), and when readily available at other larger scale (more detailed) published geologic maps to ensure accurate coincidence of boundaries. For this review, High and Medium Priority basins with discrepancies between the linework and written description were sorted as having “significant”, “major”, or “minor” geologic issues. DWR has made adjustments to basin boundaries having a significant geologic issue, and an unambiguous written description. These realignments are not an adjustment to the written text contained within the Bulletin 118 but an attempt to better capture geographically the written descriptions.

In an effort to realign locations of groundwater basins and subbasins, a process was set up to review the boundaries of all groundwater basins and subbasins to ensure they were aligned with the most current county boundaries. In the initial creation of the B118 dataset, there were some errors introduced with the use of county lines. This process step was undertaken to correct these errors. We reviewed each basin written description to provide a list of which basin boundaries needed to have their county line portions reviewed. Once we had a list of the basins that needed review, we reviewed them with the using the CalFire Counties dataset to ensure accurate coincidence of boundaries. These realignments are not an adjustment to the written text contained within the Bulletin 118 but an attempt to better capture geographically the written descriptions.

In an effort to realign locations of groundwater basins and subbasins, a process was set up to review the boundaries of all groundwater basins and subbasins to ensure they were aligned with the most current stream boundaries. In the initial creation of the B118 dataset, there were some errors introduced with the use of stream and rivers as a boundary. This process step was undertaken to correct these errors. We reviewed each basin written description to provide a list of which basin boundaries referred to a stream or river and subsequently needed to have their county line portions reviewed. Once we had a list of the basins that needed review, we reviewed them using the National Hydrography Dataset’s Hydroline dataset to ensure accurate coincidence of boundaries. These realignments are not an adjustment to the written text contained within the Bulletin 118 but an attempt to better capture geographically the written descriptions.

Following the adoption of DWR’s Basin Boundary Emergency Regulations, DWR provided an online Basin Boundary Assessment Tool (BBAT) to inform local agencies and the public about the existing Bulletin 118 groundwater basins and other relevant geologic and geographic data. DWR developed a Basin Boundary Modification Request System to enable local agencies to submit their requests for basin boundary modifications online, and the public to view those requests and provide comments. The draft approved basin boundary modifications were developed through DWR’s technical review of basin boundary modification requests and public comment made during the submission period, January 1, 2016 through March 31, 2016.DWR held a series of public meetings to present the Draft Approved Basin Boundary Modifications, provide an overview of the BBMRS and technical review process, answer clarifying questions and receive further public comments on the Draft Approved Basin Boundary Modification submissions. After the public meetings, the public comments were summarized and presented to the California Water Commission. Following consideration and potential incorporation of comments heard, DWR will publish the final basin boundary modifications. These basin boundary modifications were incorporated into the dataset.

The following edits and corrections were completed for this version (5.1): (A) Several minor typos and boundary errors were corrected by DWR, including: (1) two small erroneous polygons attributed to Santa Clara Valley East Bay Plain were removed, (2) spelling out previously abbreviated FM to FORMATION in Annapolis Ohlson Ranch Formation Highlands (3) fixed typo in Coastal Plain of Los Angeles Hollywood basin number, (4) modified the boundary of the San Joaquin Valley Westside and San Joaquin Valley Kings basins on the north and eastern edges, (5) modified the boundary of San Joaquin Valley Tulare Lake and San Joaquin Valley Tule basins east/west border, (6) modified boundary of San Joaquin Valley Merced and San Joaquin Valley Chowchilla basins, (7) modified boundary of San Joaquin Valley Merced and San Joaquin Valley Delta Mendota basins, (8) modified boundary of West Santa Cruz Terrace and Santa Cruz Mid County basins, (9) modified boundary of San Joaquin Valley Delta Mendota and San Joaquin Valley Chowchilla basins, (10) modified boundary of Kaweah and Tule basins. (B) Additionally, the schema was changed to better accommodate map labels and to better align with the groundwater elevation tracking databases within DWR.
The following edits and corrections were completed for this version (5.2): Duplicate subbasin features were deleted for Kern and Tule Subbasins.

The 2018 Basin Boundary Modifications period supports the updated version 6.0 of the Bulletin 118 Basin Boundaries. Local agencies and GSAs were eligible to request basin boundary modifications during the submission period, January 1, 2018 through September 28, 2018. The draft approved basin boundary modifications are represented by this dataset. Please review the Date_Record_Last_Edited for basin features edited in this round of modifications and the Basin Boundary Modification Request System online for details - https://sgma.water.ca.gov/basinmod/

The 2018 Basin Boundary Modifications period supports the updated version 6.0.1 of the Bulletin 118 Basin Boundaries. Local agencies and GSAs were eligible to request basin boundary modifications during the submission period, January 1, 2018 through September 28, 2018. The draft approved basin boundary modifications are represented by this dataset. Please review the Date_Record_Last_Edited for basin features edited in this round of modifications and the Basin Boundary Modification Request System online for details - https://sgma.water.ca.gov/basinmod/ This microversion release includes refined linework or attribute updates specifically related to existing BBMRs draft approvals to: North American, South Yuba, San Jacinto, San Timoteo, San Diego River Valley, Madera, Butte, Kings, Sutter, Wyandotte Creek, Santa Maria, Arroyo Grande, Los Osos Area, North San Benito, Warden Creek. Additionally, this release includes the split of the San Luis Rey Valley into Upper and Lower subbasins as mandated by AB 1944 and GIS topology error corrections.

The 2018 Basin Boundary Modifications period supports the updated version 6.1 of the Bulletin 118 Basin Boundaries. Local agencies and GSAs were eligible to request basin boundary modifications during the submission period, January 1, 2018 through September 28, 2018. The final approved basin boundary modifications are represented by this dataset. Please review the Date_Record_Last_Edited for basin features edited in this round of modifications and the Basin Boundary Modification Request System online for details - https://sgma.water.ca.gov/basinmod/ This final release includes refined linework specifically related to existing BBMRs draft approvals to: Sand Point Area, Kern County, Shasta Valley, Paso Robles Area, Fillmore, Piru, Mound, and Santa Paula. Additionally, this release includes GIS topology error corrections and an error correction from the 2016 Basin Boundary Modifications period correcting a basin name from Bunker Hill to San Bernardino.
The following edits were completed for this version (6.2): Minor correction to the boundary between the Colusa and Butte subbasins and metadata.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: The name of a basin as defined in the Bulletin 118 text or the Boundary Modification Request.
attr.attrdefs: DWR Bulletin 118 Text or Basin Boundary Modification Request System

attrdomv.udom: The basin names identified in the Bulletin 118 text or the Basin Boundary Modification Request System.

attr.attrdef: Any comments related to individual records and edits.

overview.eaover: Attributes contain detailed information about groundwater basins and subbasins.
overview.eadetcit: Please see the DWR Bulletin 118 for more details.
